entry.title: portswigger web academy
entry.content:
Thought I’d use this blog to keep track of my progress throughout the PortSwigger Web Academy, where I’m aiming to learn about common web vulnerabilities and how to exploit them. Shoutout to my mate Abdul for showing me this resource.

Server-side vulnerabilities

SQL Injection

What is an SQLi?

Put simply, it’s a web vulnerability that lets an attacker input a malicious query to access sensitive data inside a database. It could also enable them to perform denial-of-service attacks.

What are the impacts of an SQLi?

SQLi’s can compromise PII and SPII such as:

  • passwords
  • credit card details
  • personal user info (e.g. DOB, home address)
entry.summary: my progression through the web security labs on portswigger

entry.title: capture the flag participation
entry.content:
To view my CTF logs, please click this link: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1Jpl8el70ainfZIWUYiEkgDLbeuV9BrcScYEIWPF6Uqk/edit?usp=sharing

DamCTF 2024

This was my very first CTF, so I went into it with almost no knowledge on anything cybersecurity related. It was simply to get my feet wet and figure out how a CTF actually works, as I’d heard so much about them that I wanted to give it a go. Apart from the first and last flags (which were just from reading the rules), I was only close to getting one for this OSINT challenge. However, not being located in the US proved a huge disadvantage and I didn’t end up getting it. But this first step was important, and I compare it to when you throw babies into swimming pools and expect them to learn how to float based off instinct. I had absolutely no idea what I was doing, yet I ended up beating more than 100 people in the end.

UNSW SecSoc Rookie Rumble 2024

This was my second CTF, and a MASSIVE step up in performance. To be honest, the challenges were much simpler (credit to SecSoc and CSESoc for organising it in such a beginner friendly way), but I still pride myself in being able to figure out some of the challenges with little to zero knowledge on concepts such as reverse engineering, cryptography, pwning, and so on. We managed to rank 15th despite this, and it was an effort I’m quite proud of. I think this CTF will be the one I look back on if I ever get really good at these.
entry.summary: a log of the CTFs i've participated in to date
